content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple fragments of tissue. There are at least six ovoid, darkly basophilic (purple) structures that are characteristic of lymph nodes. Other tissue fragments are paler and more irregular, likely representing fibrofatty tissue or sections of the primary tumor. My initial impression is that this slide is primarily for lymph node staging in a colorectal cancer case.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, my primary task for this slide is to identify any metastatic tumor in the lymph nodes. I would systematically examine each lymph node. The green box is over the largest lymph node in the upper left quadrant. This is a logical starting point for a systematic review. I am zooming in to assess the cellular composition and architecture of this node at a higher magnification to look for any clusters of atypical cells (carcinoma) that would indicate metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area to begin the systematic evaluation of the lymph nodes for evidence of metastasis. The selected area is clearly one of the larger, more cellular lymph nodes on the slide. Examining the architecture and cellular composition at higher magnification is necessary to determine if it is a benign/reactive node or if it contains malignant tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my process involves a systematic review of every potential lymph node on the slide. The area highlighted by the green box is clearly one of these candidate lymph nodes, located in the center of the slide. I am zooming into this specific lymph node to examine its architecture and cellular composition at high magnification to determine if it contains metastatic tumor cells or if it is a benign (reactive) lymph node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this specific area because this tissue fragment, located in the upper central part of the slide, does not have the typical appearance of a reactive lymph node. Unlike the larger, uniformly purple nodes, this one is smaller, more irregular, and has a mottled appearance with a mix of basophilic (dark) and eosinophilic (pink) areas. This heterogeneity is highly suspicious for a lymph node that has been partially or completely replaced by metastatic tumor, which often elicits a desmoplastic (fibrous) response, appearing pink. It is crucial to examine such areas at high magnification to confirm or rule out the presence of malignant cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. A pathologist's task is to find all positive lymph nodes. After examining the obvious, large lymph nodes, a thorough search of the surrounding fatty tissue is crucial. The area highlighted by the green box is not one of the large, well-defined lymph nodes. Instead, it is a small, focal area within the fatty tissue that has a subtle basophilic (bluish) hue. This is suspicious for either a very small lymph node, a completely replaced lymph node, or a tumor deposit (TD). Any such focal cellular aggregate within the fat must be investigated at high power to rule out metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically evaluating each lymph node for the presence of metastatic tumor cells. I zoomed into this specific lymph node (one of the smaller central nodes) because, even at low power, it displays a suspicious feature. There is a distinct, lighter-staining, pink (eosinophilic) and irregular area within the otherwise dark purple lymphoid tissue. This 'moth-eaten' or mottled appearance is highly suggestive of the normal lymph node architecture being replaced by an infiltrating tumor, which warrants a closer, high-magnification examination to confirm the diagnosis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task here is to systematically examine every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The area indicated by the green box contains one of the smaller, discrete lymph nodes on the slide. I would zoom into this area as part of a methodical review of all tissue present. This specific node needs to be assessed at higher magnification to evaluate its architecture and cellular composition to determine if it is a positive (metastatic) or negative (reactive) lymph node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a dense and diffuse population of lymphocytes. The cells are predominantly small with dark, round nuclei and scant cytoplasm, consistent with normal lymphoid cells. There are some paler, irregular spaces which may represent lymphoid sinuses or artifactual separation. I do not see any discrete nests, glands, or clusters of atypical epithelial cells with large, pleomorphic nuclei that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field of view is that it represents benign/reactive lymphoid tissue, with no evidence of malignancy.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the architecture of a lymph node. The tissue is densely populated with lymphocytes. There are fibrous bands (pink stroma) dissecting the lymphoid parenchyma, and adipose tissue is present at the periphery (lower left). Critically, I do not see any definite nests of atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or other features characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field is that of a reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis. I would continue to scan the entire node to confirm this impression before moving to the next one.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a lymph node completely filled with a dense, monotonous population of small, round, dark-staining cells, which are lymphocytes. The normal architecture with distinct follicles and sinuses is effaced. I do not see any atypical glandular structures, clusters of large epithelial cells with pleomorphic nuclei, or significant necrosis that would indicate metastatic adenocarcinoma. The entire node appears to be replaced by lymphoid cells. My impression is that this is a lymph node that is negative for metastatic carcinoma. The dense lymphoid infiltrate is characteristic of a reactive lymph node or could potentially suggest a low-grade lymphoma, but it is definitively negative for colorectal cancer metastasis.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view confirms the suspicion of metastasis. I see extensive infiltration by malignant glands and nests of atypical epithelial cells, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. The tumor cells have large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei and are set within a dense, pink, desmoplastic stroma. There are residual aggregates of lymphocytes, suggesting this is a lymph node that has been almost entirely replaced by tumor. Adipose tissue and small nerve bundles are also visible in the periphery. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node, heavily involved by metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see mature adipose tissue (large, empty-looking fat cells). Within this fat, there is a nodular aggregate of cells. This aggregate consists of two main components: a dense collection of small, dark lymphocytes, and clusters of larger, atypical epithelial cells. These atypical cells have irregular, hyperchromatic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and eosinophilic cytoplasm, forming poorly-defined glandular structures. There is no clear residual lymph node architecture (like a capsule or sinuses). My impression is that this is a focus of metastatic adenocarcinoma. Given the lack of a definite lymph node structure, this would most likely be classified as a tumor deposit (TD), which is a significant prognostic finding. This is a positive finding for metastatic disease.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image confirms the presence of metastatic carcinoma within the lymph node. A significant portion of the normal lymphoid parenchyma is effaced and replaced by malignant glandular structures and irregular nests of tumor cells. These tumor cells are pleomorphic, with large, hyperchromatic nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm. There is associated necrosis and a desmoplastic stromal response. The remaining lymphoid tissue is pushed to the periphery. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing a macrometastasis of adenocarcinoma, consistent with origin from a colorectal primary.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a lymph node surrounded by mature adipose tissue (fat). The normal architecture of the lymph node is preserved but shows reactive changes. Specifically, there is prominent follicular hyperplasia, characterized by numerous, well-defined lymphoid follicles with germinal centers. The cellular population consists of a mixed population of lymphocytes, with no evidence of atypical epithelial cells, abnormal gland formation, or necrotic debris that would suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis.
